Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 54265-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2020 
 
 
 
Republic  of Kazakhstan:  COVID-19  Solidarity  Fund 
for Kazakhstan  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 31 October 2020)

$1.00  =  T432.68 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB   –  Asian Development Bank 
  COVID-19  –  coronavirus disease  
  MLSPP  –  Ministry of Labor and Social Protection of Population 
  SFK  –  Solidarity Fund for Kazakhstan

  TA  –  technical assistance 
  UNDP  –  United Nations Development Programme

Vice-President  Shixin Chen, Operations 1 
Director General  Werner E. Liepach, Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) 
Deputy Director General  Nianshan Zhang, CWRD 
Country Director  Nariman Mannapbekov, Kazakhstan Resident Mission (KARM), 
CWRD

CONTENTS 
Page 
KNOWLEDGE AND SUPPORT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AT A GLANCE 
I.  INTRODUCTION  1 
II.  ISSUES  1 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  2 
A.  Impact and Outcome  2 
B.  Outputs and Activities  2 
C.  Cost and Financing  3 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  3 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  5 
 
 
APPENDIXES 
1.  Design and Monitoring Framework  6 
2.  Cost Estimates and Financing Plan  9 
3.  List of Linked Documents  10

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will assist Kazakhstan in fighting 
the negative impact on the local labor market of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) 
pandemic by minimizing the effect on the most vulnerable parts of the population and preparing 
for post-crisis socioeconomic development based on newly emerging industries, professions, and 
jobs. The Solidarity Fund for Kazakhstan (SFK), created by government agencies with technical 
and financial assistance from development partners, will provide the training and retraining to 
build capacity and skills in emerging sectors such as agriculture, e-commerce, and information 
technology.  
 
2.  The TA is aligned with the support measures and new economic development strategy 
introduced by the Government of Kazakhstan in response to the challenges caused by the 
COVID-19 pandemic. The TA’s objective is to assist the government in providing timely labor 
market support measures to address crises caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.1 The TA is 
included in ADB’s country operations business plan for Kazakhstan, 2021–2023.2  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Kazakhstan is facing tremendous challenges as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic and 
the reduction in oil prices since early 2020, which have jointly resulted in an unprecedented 
economic and social crisis. The government has adopted programs that seek to diversify the 
economy, but Kazakhstan remains heavily dependent on extractive industries, with over 70% of 
export revenues derived from basic commodities, especially oil and gas. This production structure, 
which is typical of countries affected by so-called “Dutch disease”,3 creates pronounced economic 
vulnerabilities that amplify the impact of the ongoing crisis. 
 
4.  The economic crisis in Kazakhstan is impacting business activities, especially those of 
small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) with the services sector contracting by 5.6% in the 
first half of 2020. The full impact on employment has yet to be assessed, but COVID-19-induced 
measures caused 4.2 million people to be suspended or laid off during the quarantine.4 A survey 
conducted by Atameken5 (an entrepreneur’s association in Kazakhstan) in August 2020 suggests 
that local firms will likely dismiss more than 35% of their employees because of the COVID-19 
pandemic assessments of the impact of the crisis on local employment vary, but government 
agency announcements suggest that out of 8.5 million employed people, over 2 million are 
expected to temporarily or permanently lose their jobs. Over 3.7 million people are expected to 
have reduced or no income during the pandemic and will receive social payments from the 
government. A survey indicates 26% of female respondents lost their jobs or faced a reduction in 
paid working hours, while 81% of women reported their time spent on domestic work increased.6 
Traditionally, women are predominantly employed in tourism, hospitality, and service sector jobs.7 
 
 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 15 May 2020. 
2  ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan: Kazakhstan, 2021–2023. Manila.  
3   Kojo, Naoko C. Demystifying Dutch Disease. Policy Research Working Paper. World Bank Group, 2014 Washington, 
DC.  
4  Ministry of Labor and Social Protection data. 
5   National Chamber of Entrepreneurs, research results of COVID-19 impact on SMEs.  
6  United Nations (UN) Women Kazakhstan and the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA).The Impact of Covid-19 
on Women’s and Men’s Lives and Livelihoods.2020.Nur-Sultan. 
7  Republic of Kazakhstan, Ministry of National Economy, Committee on Statistics. Gender.

2 
 
5.  Social discontent and fragmentation are expected to increase as the proportion of the work 
force being laid off increases and the most vulnerable people experience the negative economic 
impact of the prolonged containment measures (e.g., social distancing and quarantines). These 
measures have also served to substantially transform the labor market. Several professions are 
struggling  as  a  result  of  reduced  demand  for  traditional  skills  and  the  ongoing  significant 
transformation in and the increased use of remote working arrangements, leading to a surge in 
unemployment. Impacts on services and manufacturing production have resulted in massive 
layoffs. The tourism industry has been heavily affected as countries closed borders and blocked 
the movement of people to contain the spread of COVID-19. Increasing displacement in the labor 
market and the low capacity of the labor force to adapt to new job opportunities will likely lead to 
deep social and economic impacts that push more people into poverty.    
 
6.  Through  training  programs  and  a  subsequent  increase  in  labor  force  capacity  in 
Kazakhstan, the TA will help the government achieve the targets set out in President Tokayev’s 
state of the nation address on 1 September 2020, specifically increasing the contribution of SMEs 
to gross domestic product to 35% by 2025, and increasing the number of people employed to 4 
million.8 
 
7.  The  proposal  from  the  Ministry  of  National  Economy  to  establish  SFK  was  further 
elaborated through a series of informal meetings among prospective partners, with subsequent 
support  provided  to  Kazakhstan  in  March–October  2020  by  ADB,  the  United  Nations 
Development Programme (UNDP), the World Bank, and other development partners. The SFK 
will focus on delivering training and re-training programs to help poor and vulnerable people who 
lost their jobs due to the pandemic find new jobs in the post-COVID-19 economy. Initially, the SFK 
was intended to also assist with the provision of material relief (food and medicine) and the 
creation of an online platform for the provision of public services to SMEs. These activities were, 
however, supported by ADB’s Asia Pacific Disaster Response Fund and other government 
programs that were not anticipated during the concept stage of the TA. The Asia Pacific Disaster 
Response Fund approved a $3.0 million emergency grant9 to the government to provide medical 
supplies and life-saving equipment in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The government 
updated its request for the SFK to focus on retraining and skills upgrading to develop capabilities 
and expertise in industries and sectors that are expected to provide most business development 
opportunities in the post-COVID-19 environment. Joint financing and management of TA activities 
by ADB, UNDP, and the World Bank in collaboration with the government are expected to produce 
relevant synergies and complementarities.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: supporting measures and new economic 
strategy introduced by the government to respond to COVID-19 challenges. The TA’s outcome is 
timely labor market support measures provided by the government to address crises caused by 
the COVID-19 pandemic.10 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
 
8 President of Kazakhstan State of the Nation address, September 1, 2020.  
9 Approved by the President of ADB on 27 Aug 2020. COVID-19 Emergency Response.  
10 The list of the government support measures for COVID-19 outbreak.

3 
 
9.  Output 1: Report on emerging professions for Kazakhstan prepared. To properly 
design and deliver new labor-related training programs, the SFK will support conducting an 
analysis of the professions needed in the post-COVID-19 environment as part of the ongoing 
initiative  of  the  Ministry  of  Labor  and  Social  Protection  of  Population  (MLSPP)  and  BTS 
Education.11 Building skills in the COVID-19 context will be integrated into a labor market 
modernization roadmap developed by the MLSPP under the framework of the World Bank’s Skills 
and  Jobs  Project,12 including  online  skills  enhancement  training  for  people  who  are  (i) 
unemployed and unproductively self-employed, and (ii) currently employed but in need of training. 
Concurrently, the SFK will assist with developing individual employment schemes supported by 
mentoring, counseling, and orientation. This output will be delivered from December 2020 until 
April 2021. 
 
10.  Output 2: Training programs for skills development delivered. The SFK will develop 
and deliver a complete set of training and retraining programs for skills development to help poor 
and vulnerable people who lost their jobs due to COVID-19 find new job opportunities in the post-
pandemic environment, including women in rural areas. Such training can be extended to 
reskilling and upskilling of those workers who are at risk of losing their jobs as a result of problems 
adapting to emerging needs for skills and new business processes. To accomplish this, the SFK 
will help quantify total job losses in the country and assess the impact of COVID-19 on individual 
and family incomes. International and local experts will help identify emerging industries and 
sectors in the post-COVID-19 pandemic environment and design focused training programs for 
the local workforce to serve both national and international markets. Many firms will realize the 
need to realign their business processes, products and services to new standards of production, 
trading, packaging and delivery, and the successful restarting of business operations post-
COVID-19 will require new skills and adaptation of vocational training. The output will be delivered 
in close collaboration with MLSPP and coordinated with the World Bank’s ongoing Skills and Jobs 
Project (footnote 12). This output will be delivered from January 2021 until December 2022. 
 
11.  Output 3: Training programs for  small and medium-sized enterprises to enter 
emerging  industries  delivered.  The  SFK  will  develop  and  deliver  training  programs  in 
collaboration with the Damu Entrepreneurship Development Fund to assist SMEs enter emerging 
industries that are expected to emerge in the post-COVID-19 economy, such as agriculture, e-
commerce, and information technology. The programs will also support women entrepreneurs 
and capacity building. Online programs will be targeted to improve existing skills and provide 
education on new competencies required to promote entrepreneurship activity. Courses will be 
delivered in accordance with business needs and provided in the Kazakh and Russian languages. 
This output will be delivered from January 2021 until December 2022. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The indicative key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The Ministry of National Economy will be the executing agency and will facilitate the overall 
coordination of all SFK activities for the government. ADB will administer the TA through the 
 
11 BTS Education. Our projects.  
12  World Bank. Republic of Kazakhstan: Skills and Jobs Project. Washington, DC. 2015.

4 
 
Kazakhstan Resident Mission of its’ Central and West Asia Department,  and in close coordination 
with relevant sector and thematic groups of the Sustainable Development and Climate Change 
Department.   
 
14.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  December 2020 – December 2022 
Executing agency  Ministry of National Economy of the Republic of Kazakhstan 
Implementing agency  UNDP 
Procurement  ADB and UNDP will implement an Administrative Arrangement, 
under a revised and updated version of the Memorandum of 
Understanding between the two organizations signed on 12 April 
2019 (this has been applied in projects for the promotion of the 
Sustainable Development Goals in Kazakhstan). In addition, ADB’s 
prior clearance must be secured before the signing of any 
procurement or consultant contracts to be financed under the 
Administrative Arrangement. 
Disbursement  Disbursement of TA resources will follow ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended from time to time). 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, TA = technical assistance, UNDP = United Nations Development Programme 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
15.  UNDP will serve as the SFK’s administrator on behalf of all cofinanciers and it will be 
responsible for procurement, consultant recruitment, and financial reporting. However, ADB’s 
prior clearance must be secured before the signing of any procurement or consultant contracts to 
be financed under the Administrative Arrangement between ADB and UNDP. The SFK will not be 
a separate legal entity and will be recognized as part of UNDP. To administer and manage ADB’s 
contribution, UNDP will set up a dedicated project in its information system, Enterprise Resources 
Programme Atlas, in line with UNDP rules and regulations. The detailed role of UNDP in the TA 
and its financial and technical relationships with ADB is defined in the Statement of Intent, which 
will be signed following approval of the TA by the government and UNDP.13 The SFK will be 
governed by a steering committee, which will serve as the facility’s main decision-making body. 
The steering committee will be chaired by the Minister of the Ministry of National Economy and 
will include one representative from each of the participating organizations (ADB, MLSPP, UNDP, 
and the World Bank). The steering committee will have the authority to encourage contributions 
to SFK from other organizations and, if required to reallocate these contributions in favor of new 
beneficiaries, subject to relevant ADB policies.  
 
16.  Transfer of funds. Transfer of funds to UNDP will be governed by the Administrative 
Arrangement on the basis of the Memorandum of Understanding signed by ADB and UNDP on 
12 April 2019.14 The details of proposed disbursement and funds flow arrangement are described 
in UNDP’s Financial Management Assessment.15 The funding will not lead to any potential 
adverse environmental and/or social impacts.  
 
13  Statement of Intent between the United Nations Development Programme and the Asian Development Bank 
(accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
14 Administrative Arrangement between the United Nations Development Programme and the Asian Development Bank 
(accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
15 Financial Management Assessment, Transfer of Funds, and Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan 
(accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

5 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis, to 
the Government of Kazakhstan for the COVID-19 Solidarity Fund for Kazakhstan, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 1  6

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Output 1 Report on emerging professions for Kazakhstan prepared  
1.1 Develop TORs and hire consultants to assess COVID-19 impact on labor market (Q4 2020–Q1 
2021) 
1.2 Quantify total job losses in Kazakhstan due to COVID-19’s impact on men and women using sex-
disaggregated data (Q1 2021)  
1.3 Assess which people are the most affected people by social group, region, and sector of 
employment using sex-disaggregated data (Q2 2021) 
1.4 Identify emerging industries and sectors in the post-COVID-19 pandemic environment and their 
potential for generating new jobs for men and women, using sex-disaggregated data (Q2 2021) 
 
2.  Output 2 Training programs for skills development delivered 
2.1 Develop TORs and hire consultants to deliver training programs for skills development (Q1 2021) 
2.2 Assist with the development of individual employment schemes supported by mentoring, 
counseling, and orientation in coordination with existing employment centers (Q1 2021–Q4 2022) 
2.3 Deliver training and/or retraining programs for skills development for the unemployed, 
unproductively self-employed, and employed in need of training (Q1 2021–Q4 2022) 
 
3.  Output 3: Training programs for SMEs to enter emerging industries delivered 
 
3.1 Develop TORs and hire consultants to develop training programs for SMEs focused on entering 
emerging industries (Q1 2021–2 2021) 
3.2 Deliver gender inclusive training and/or retraining programs for skills development in emerging 
industries for SMEs (Q1 2021–Q4 2022) 
3.3 Assist with the delivery of the government’s measures to fight the impact of COVID-19 on the 
labor market (Q1 2021–Q4 2022) 
3.4 Provide training and/or retraining services for SMEs most affected by COVID-19 (Q1 2021–Q4 
2022) 
 
TA Management Activities 
Preparation of TA completion report (Q4 2022) 
 
Inputs 
ADB: $1,000,000 (TASF- other sources) 
Assumptions for Partner Financing  
Outputs not administered by ADB that are necessary to reach the outcome include. 
Training programs for skills development delivered: the government of Kazakhstan, UNDP,WB 
Training programs for SMEs to enter emerging industries delivered: UNDP

WB = World Bank. 
Source: Asian Development Bank.
